RTIL-system: a Real-Time Interactive L-system for 3D interactions with virtual plants
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 15 July 2011

RTIL-system: a Real-Time Interactive L-system for 3D interactions with virtual plants

  • Ludovic Hamon1,
  • Emmanuelle Richard1,
  • Paul Richard1,
  • Rachid Boumaza2 &
  • Jean-Louis Ferrier1 

Virtual Reality volume 16, pages151–160(2012)Cite this article

  • 400 Accesses

  • 4 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The L-system is a rewriting process based on formal grammar and is used to generate 3D, dynamic structures such as virtual plants and fractal graphics. In previous works, we highlighted that existing L-system software applications and programs are limited, either in terms of human interaction or in terms of modelling. In particular, few of them allow the user to interact with virtual plants during their growth. Our own L-system engine was developed and called the real-time interactive L-system (RTIL-system). The RTIL-system covers most important L-system extensions such as parametric and context-sensitive features. Furthermore, real-time interactions with the user and the environment with respect to L-system formalism are available. This paper presents an RTIL-system focusing on human interaction, the Partial Interactive Derivation (PID) concept and further progress by the extension of PID to context-sensitive rules. To illustrate the potential of the RTIL-system, the effect of various interactive tasks such as sub-axis additions, pruning and bending on the subsequent dynamic development of virtual plants is described.

Introduction

Virtual plants are computer simulations of the growth, development and deployment of plants in three-dimensional (3D) space. Most current, virtual plant models focus on plant architecture and describe plants as individual entities. They are used to simulate the spatial features of plants and output the 3D architecture as realistic images. Over the last decades, several software applications have been developed. For example, Amap is based on statistical measurements, Markov chains and the Monte-Carlo method (Cirad 2011). XFrog is specifically developed for tree modelling (Lintermann and Deussen 1999). VLab can generate, order and save an amount of virtual plant models coming from different programs (Federl and Prusinkiewicz 1999). GreenLab adopts the AMAP discretisation scheme and dual-scale automation (Hu et al. 2003).

One of the most interesting software applications is L-Studio software with cpfg and lpfg applications created in 1999 at the University of Calgary (Canada) by Prusinciewicz and co-workers (Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000b; Karwowski 2002). It is based on the L-system, a parallel, rewriting process inspired by formal grammar (Lindenmayer 1968; Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990). Belonging to the 'graftal' class according to Smith (1984), L-systems can be used to generate 3D virtual plants with realistic morphological and physiological features.

Nowadays, in order to carry out advanced studies, or to improve the realism of virtual plants, domains such as botany, agronomy, forestry, ecology, urban design and video games require real-time interaction in these virtual models. In addition, virtual reality (VR) or augmented reality (AR) applications can offer haptic rendering and accurate 3D interfaces for tasks involving virtual plant manipulation.

In a previous work, we highlighted that existing L-system software applications and programs are limited either in terms of human interaction or in terms of modelling. Furthermore, only some of them are open source. The proposed L-system engine in this paper was developed and called the real-time interactive L-system (RTIL-system) (Hamon et al. 2010). The RTIL-system allows (i) collision detection and haptic rendering of the virtual plant, (ii) data transmission and reception with the environment and user, thanks to dedicated communication functions and procedures, and (iii) interactive properties of the graphic representation with respect to L-system formalism thanks to the Partial Interactive Derivation concept.

This paper presents further progress of the RTIL-system. The Partial Interactive Derivation concept is covered in detail, and its potential for the graphic modelling of plants is discussed. The Partial Interactive Derivation extension to context-sensitive rules and new tasks, such as sub-axis additions and angle variations on dynamic virtual plants, are also described throughout the paper.

After an introduction to L-system formalism in Sect. 2, the related research is considered in Sect. 3, focusing on real-time interactive L-system applications. Section 4 is dedicated to discussing the basic features and implementation of the RTIL-system, whereas Sect. 5 describes real-time interactions with the environment and user, Partial Interactive Derivation and its extension to context-sensitive rules with corresponding applications. Finally, the paper concludes with a discussion regarding system progress and recommendations for future work.

Introduction to the L-system

Elementary notions

The L-system is a formal language that was first used to describe the development and proliferation of simple multi-cellular organisms (Lindenmayer 1968). Lindenmayer and Prusinkiewicz developed and extended this language to model plants (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990). The L-system is a triplet (V, w, P), V being an alphabet, w being an axiom and P being a set of production rules. The couple (p, s), belonging to a set of production rules, is composed of a predecessor (p) and a successor (s). A derivation process replaces the axiom symbols of predecessors with the corresponding successors. If there is no corresponding predecessor, then the symbol is replaced by itself. After the axiom is completely reviewed, the string obtained is called the ‘L-string’. Parametric L-systems provided important improvements, in which each symbol (called a “module”) may take on a finite number of real parameters (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990). Furthermore, a logical condition was added to each production rule that is applied if: (i) the current symbol is equal to the rule predecessor, (ii) the number of parameters of the symbol is equal to the number of parameters of the rule predecessor and (iii) if the rule condition is true (Fig. 1). Following this, Lindenmayer and Prusinkiewicz proposed the turtle geometry concept (belonging to LOGO Language) to provide a geometrical interpretation of the L-string. This approach is based on an imaginary turtle that walks and draws lines. In two dimensions, the turtle geometry concept is based on the triplet (x, y, a), (x, y) being the position of the turtle, and ’a’ being the yaw angle of the turtle’s movement. A simple example of a context-free deterministic DOL-system is given in Fig. 2a. The following interpretation symbols are introduced with a stack that saves the state of the turtle (all its parameters: position, orientation, …) as follows (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990):

  • F: move a d distance forward and draw a line.

  • (x, y, a) ⇒ (x + d × cos(a), y + d × sin(a), a)

  • f: move a d distance forward without drawing a line.

  • (x, y, a) ⇒ (x + d × cos(a), y + d × sin(a), a)

  • +: turn left by angle o. (x, y, a) ⇒ (x, y, a + o)

  • −: turn right by angle o. (x, y, a) ⇒ (x, y, a − o)

  • [: push the current turtle state to the stack.

  • ]: pop the previous turtle state from the stack.

Since then, numerous interpretation symbols have been proposed (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990; Mech et al. 2005).

Evolution and extensions

In the 1970s and 1980s, several new forms of L-systems appeared. For example, stochastic L-systems were developed to add a level of probability to each production rule (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990). This feature allows the application of several rules for the same symbol, which was not possible with deterministic L-systems. Pseudo L-systems have rule predecessors that can be made up of several modules (Prusinkiewicz 1986). Another interesting extension of L-systems is context-sensitive L-systems (called D1L-systems or D2L-systems, (Fig. 2b). In a left (respectively right) context-sensitive L-system, a rule is applied only if the left (respectively right) symbol of the current symbol is equal to the left (respectively right) context of the current rule predecessor (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990).

Different applications with advanced graphic rendering then appeared. For example, Baele and co-workers generated real-time trees with different detail levels, including lighting effects and animation in the wind, by using GPU capabilities (Baele and Warzée 2005). From the 1990s to present, virtual plants generated by L-systems explicitly described the spatial distribution of plant organs in three dimensions as a collection of interconnected components. Furthermore, they modelled the morphological and physiological aspects (Favre et al. 2007) and the dynamics of plant populations (Bornhofen and Lattaud 2007; Prusinkiewicz 2011).

Related works on interactive L-systems

Many software applications dedicated to plant modelling exist and provide real-time basic interaction with virtual plants, such as rotation or zoom effects on the entire model. These interactions use the computer mouse and the keyboard (Federl and Prusinkiewicz 1999; Hu et al. 2003; Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000b; Karwowski 2002). However, some approaches have focused on interaction with the environment such as the Open L-system and a specific module called the ‘communication module’ (Mech 1997; Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000b). This kind of L-system offered several interesting features such as the handling of collisions between plant organs or components, water dispersal in the soil, light distribution and several other interactions. However, a communication module was required for each module to send the entire topological structure to the environment. In the same way, Bornhofen et al. used a DOL-system to model different kinds of plant in a virtual garden. These plants grew according to some environmental factors such as sunlight and soil components (Bornhofen and Lattaud 2007). In addition, the virtual plants’ morphological and physiological aspects were related to their competition for resources.

In the field of education, another interesting example was the Garden Alive system developed by Teajin and Woontack (2006). By mixing a real garden and a virtual garden, and by using some detection sensors and tangible interfaces, the user could provide water and nutrients to the virtual plant being studied and influence its exposure to light. This was an adapted system in terms of efficiency and realism. Gilroy et al. described an Augmented Reality art installation (Gilroy et al. 2008). A virtual tree, defined by an L-system and influenced by the perceived negative or positive emotional state of the spectators, grew or faded on a marker. The L-system parameters taken into account were colour, branching, speed of growth and branch orientation. In these two pieces of work, the process that allows parameters to change in real time, in that kind of interactive L-system, was not described.

Advanced interaction techniques have also been investigated. For example, Power et al. developed an interesting, interactive L-system called ILSA (Interactive L-String Arranger), based on the cpfg engine (Power et al. 1999; Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000b). The user could select plant components using a mouse. The selection could be made by inserting two points on a branch (a starting and an ending point). Operations, such as bending or pruning, were possible. Interactive manipulations were executed in semi-real time, using a basic graphic rendering. However, the relations between such graphic modifications and the consequences on the L-string were not detailed.

More recently, Onishi and co-workers presented a DOL-system in which 3D turtle Cartesian coordinates were directly sent to the environment (Onishi et al. 2003, 2006). They used a magnetic tracking system to generate the trunk and the branches from hand movements. Corresponding L-strings were generated and branches were attached to the trunk at some specified connecting points. The user could also specify some geometric primitives or draw silhouettes in which parts of plant would develop. Furthermore, a component included in the selected zone could be pruned, rotated, etc. These studies provided some interesting 3D interactions, but the predefined connecting point concept did not seem to be coherent with a bracketed L-system (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990). Indeed, bracket symbols were specifically dedicated to sub-axis modelling for the production of realistic branching. Finally the models were all based on simple, non-parametric DOL-systems, limiting both the modelling possibilities and the animation.

The RTIL-system: basic features

Description

The RTIL-system is a C++ library. It allows the creation and editing of a script file describing the L-system model. Once this script has been created, the RTIL-system generates the L-string and the geometric features of each interpretation module (like the positions and orientations of the turtle). The graphic part is achieved, thanks to the OpenGL library with optional stereoscopic features for depth sensation enhancement. The RTIL-system takes into account deterministic, context-free, context-sensitive, parametric, non-parametric and pseudo L-system features. Homomorphism and decomposition rules can also be applied (Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000b; Karwowski 2002). The RTIL-system is based on the cpfg concept and model and uses similar syntax. A typical RTIL-system rule is presented as follows:

$${\text{cg}}< {\text{pred}} >{\text{cd}}:C_{{\text{a}}} \,{\text{cond}}\,C_{{\text{d}}} \to {\text{Succ}}, $$

where pred is the predecessor, cg is the left context, cd is the right context, cond is a logical proposition, C a and C b are C language instructions and succ is the successor.

An example, script 1 with its graphic representation is given below and illustrated in Fig. 3. The derivation length is the number of required derivations. The global variable c 2 counts the number of calls on the second rule during each derivation. The global variable s 2 counts the application number of the second rule during the entire process.

The concept of homomorphism, defined by Prusinkiewicz et al., consists of an optional and additional derivation process with interpretation rules (Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000a). These specific rules that follow the homomorphism keyword in the script have been introduced by Kurth (1994). Interpretation rules do not affect the sequence of generated strings, but constitute a homomorphism of these strings. After derivation steps, homomorphism creates a temporary word by replacing modules, in the derived L-string, by other modules with an assigned 2D/3D geometric interpretation (cf. Sect. 2.1). Through homomorphism, each plant component possesses its own modelling and interpretation rules as well as its own graphic representation.

Global generation process

With the homomorphism process, to obtain a graphic representation, two important items are required: the L-string (item 1) and the temporary word (item 2). An example of a global generation process is described in Fig. 3: the derivation process starts by first replacing axiom A by I(1)[+A][−A]I(1)A thanks to rule (r1) (derivation 1). Thereafter, with the application of rules (r1) and (r2) to the corresponding modules of the current L-string, the final L-string is created (item 1). The homomorphism process can start with only one derivation using rules (r3) and (r4) on the corresponding L-string modules. The result is the creation of a temporary word (item 2) leading to graphic interpretation.

The RTIL-system: interactive features

Data transmission and reception

The RTIL-system allows data transmission and reception with the environment, thanks to dedicated communication functions and procedures; thereby, local and global variables and other information are available to an environment that can simulate light, collisions, soil distribution, etc. Each graphic piece of information linked to each interpretation module (such as the positions and orientations of the turtle) can be used by programs including the RTIL library. An example of interaction with the environment is illustrated in Fig. 4. In this case, virtual plant growth is constrained to the outside of a sphere (Hamon et al. 2010).

Graphic interactions and component selection

The RTIL-system allows graphic components to be selected, thanks to the integration of different types of 3D interaction devices such as the Phantom Omni TM desktop haptic interface from Sensable. The process is achieved by using a collision detection algorithm involving a spherical cursor (Fig. 7a) and a geometrical model associated with the selected component and hence, with the selected module (Hamon et al. 2010). The RTIL-system also provides haptic rendering during the manipulation of the virtual plant. Figure 5 shows a user performing tasks with feedback under stereoscopic viewing conditions.

Graphic interaction with the virtual plant requires the three following steps: (i) to select one (or more) 3D component(s), (ii) to find the corresponding module(s) in the L-string (see the blue-dotted arrows in Fig. 3 or the identification process in Fig. 9) and (iii) to apply an action to the selected module(s) (cf. Sect. 5.3). For example, a deletion task consists of the removal of graphic elements coupled with the deletion of the corresponding modules in the L-string (cf Sect. 5.3.1).

Some difficulties may appear when the process links the graphic component to the corresponding L-string module. The homomorphism concept and pseudo L-systems allow the writing of different scripts that among them generate the same graphic shape and behaviour. This leads to two problems:

  • a bijective problem: let us consider script 1 with the first homomorphic rule \(I(x) \rightarrow F(x)\) being replaced by this one: \(I(x) \rightarrow F(x/2)F(x/2)\). This change leads to the same graphic rendering and behaviour, but the application is no longer bijective.

  • a semantic problem: for example, let us consider the three modules A, B, and C with one parameter each, respectively, determining the length, the angle and the colour of a line. The following homomorphic rule can be written: \(A(x)B(y)C(z) \rightarrow;(z)+(y)F(x)\). In this case, the selection of the F module could possibly lead to the selection of the C module instead of A in the L-string. This obviously depends on the links built between the L-string and the temporary word during the homomorphism process.

Let us consider the following homomorphic rule: \(X_{1}(\ldots{})\ldots{}X_{n}(\ldots{}) \rightarrow Y_{1}(\ldots{})\ldots{}Y_{p}(\ldots{})\), the RTIL links built between the temporary modules (TW) and the L-string (LS) modules are described in Fig. 6.

In Fig. 6a n = p, the (TW) modules are successively linked to the (LS) modules in the same order. In Fig. 6b n > p, for any n higher than p, the (LS) modules are not linked. In this case, the X 3 module cannot be selected. In Fig. 6c n < p, for any p higher than n, the (TW) modules are linked to the last (LS) module. In this case, the selection of the X 2 module can be done either by selecting the Y 2 module or by the Y 3 module selection. In Fig. 6d n = p, the homomorphic rule application leads to the creation of a ‘son’ node. The ‘son’ node is not linked to the (LS) modules and cannot be selected. In this case, Y 3 does not have a corresponding L-string module and therefore cannot be selected.

Thus, apart from L-systems without a homomorphism process, selection tasks on any graphic module necessarily require that both the following propositions be respected: (1) the predecessor of each homomorphic rule has the same number of modules as the corresponding successor with the same semantic order, and (2) a homomorphic rule cannot lead to the creation of a new ‘son’ node in the data structure, the symbols ‘]’, ‘[’ must not be used in a homomorphic rule successor.

Interaction of selected components

Two interactions are described in the following sections: deletion and pruning, and Partial Interactive Derivation. For this study, each interaction can be performed on selected components using the corresponding button of the Phantom OmniTM stylus.

Deletion and pruning

Graphic components selected by the user can be pruned. This leads to the deletion of the corresponding modules in the L-string (Hamon et al. 2010). Figure 7 illustrates a pruning task: the user selects an internode using the Phantom Omni TM (Fig. 7a and b) and cuts the stem (Fig. 7c).

Partial Interactive Derivation: presentation and applications

The RTIL-system introduces a new type of derivation called Partial Interactive Derivation (PID). PID is defined by one or more derivation steps with specific rules only applied to selected modules, and called interaction rules. A new keyword Interaction is inserted in the script file and followed by a finite set of rules dedicated to PID (see script 2 in Fig. 8). In the case of no interaction rules existing, classic rules replace them. A large set of interactive tasks is possible with PID depending on the interaction rules written.

For example, Fig. 8 shows the interactive development of a branching structure inspired by two classic examples of plant-like structures generated by bracketed 0L-systems (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990). Note that the colour modules are omitted in script 2 for simplification purposes. Figure 9 details the complete process that allows the application of a PID. In Fig. 8b, c: first the user successively selects one or more components of his choice on the graphic representation, thanks to a 3D-interface device. In this example, the user successively “touches” three components. The identification process finds the corresponding, selected modules in the temporary word, and there after finds the corresponding, selected modules in the L-string. The PID process applies a parallel derivation with the interactive rule A \(\rightarrow\) I(1)[+A]I(1)[−A]A only on selected modules. Once the L-string has been modified, the homomorphism process starts, leading to a new temporary word and, finally, the graphic interpretation is updated. If there are no homomorphic rules, the identification process directly finds the selected modules in the L-string and, once the L-string is updated by PID, the graphic interpretation occurs.

Other examples illustrating the PID process have been shown in previous works in which a user created a mutated “Koch Fractal snowflake”, and added an insect on to a virtual plant stem that influenced a budding effect (Hamon et al. 2010).

Partial Interactive Derivation: extension to context-sensitive rules

L-system interpretation symbols can be classified in two categories:

  • (1) Interpretation symbols that are linked to geometrical primitives: F(d) = move forward a step of length d and draw a line segment, @o(d) = draw a circle of diameter d, etc.

  • (2) Interpretation symbols that are linked to geometrical transformations or other features: ; (n) = increase the value of the current colour index, +(o) = turn left by angle o (yaw angle), etc.

Interpretation symbols from category 2 cannot be selected with the selection method described in Sect. 5.2 Furthermore, if the user, for example, wants to turn left by angle o an internode I of length i, the following interaction rule can be written and applied on the desired internode: ‘\(I(i) \rightarrow+(o)I(i)\)’. However, by adding +(o) module to the L-string, this process can quickly increase the L-string length following the interaction rule application number.

To overcome this problem and interact with interpretation symbols from category 2, the Partial Interactive Derivation is extended to context-sensitive rules. The Partial Interactive Derivation is defined by one or more derivation steps with interaction rules applied to:

  • selected modules, if the interaction rule is context-free,

  • selected modules, or, modules with left and right contexts composed of selected modules (cg and cd composed of selected modules, see Sect. 4.1), if the interaction rule is context-sensitive.

In the case of no Interaction rules existing, usual rules replace them. The writing rule order in the script determines the rule application priority in the case of:

  • a context-free rule with a predecessor composed of selected modules,

  • and another context-sensitive rule composed of a context with the same selected modules.

Thanks to this new definition, to turn left by angle o an internode I of length i, the following interaction rule can be written and applied if the I module is selected: “\( +(x) >I(i) \rightarrow +(x+o)\)”.

With PID, interactions such as bending components, partial development, elongation and reduction of components, breaking, insertion of elements, etc., are available. Figures 10, 11 and 12 show the interactive evolution of a plant using the following interaction rules (the module parameters are not detailed):

  • (r5): \(+(x)>I(...) \rightarrow +(x-10)\)

  • (r6): \(I(...):\{g=g+1\}* \rightarrow[\textbackslash(g\times90)+(45) S(...)]I(...)\)

(r5) decreases the yaw angle x if there is internode I close to a + module. (r6) adds a new sub-axis S before a selected internode I with rolling angle equal to g × 90 (g is an integer initialised at 0, increasing its value by 1 each time (r6) is applied) and a yaw angle equal to 45°. Note that a tropism effect is added in the following examples (Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000b). The original structure is shown in Fig. 10a. Three components are successively selected by the user and (r6) is applied in b. Three sub-axes grow with classic derivations in c, d and e. A cutting task is presented in Fig. 11. The user selects an internode on the main axis in a and cuts it in b. Finally, Fig. 12 shows the successive selection of three components in a and the result of (r5) application in b that leads to the yaw angle variation. This global process is successively reiterated twice on the same three components, and the results are shown in c and d.

As far as L-system concept and formalism is concerned, Partial Interactive Derivation hopes to open L-system formalism to advanced interactions whereby the user can create, edit and control partial or entire derivation processes and hence become an important element of the model’s evolution.

All shown examples and interactions were executed in real time with a frame rate greater than 60 FPS (Frames Per Second). The maximum generation time including user interactions did not exceed a few seconds (maximum 15 s).

Conclusion and future research

A Real-Time Interactive L-system (RTIL-system) engine has been presented in this paper. Based on the cpfg (Prusinkiewicz et al. 2000b; Mech et al. 2005) model and concept, the main point of this contribution is to offer a new method that allows a user to interact in real time with the 3D graphic representation of a plant, while preserving L-system formalism. The development of a new derivation type named Partial Interactive Derivation (PID) and its extension to context-sensitive rules, allows the interactive development and evolution of such virtual models with correct modifications of the underlying data structure called the L-string. Depending on the implemented interactive rules, a large set of tasks is available, such as bending components, partial development, elongation and reduction of components, breaking, insertion of elements, etc.

Nevertheless, the real-time aspect can be discussed. Depending on the desired graphic result and depending on the L-system script, the performance can decrease. The first point has been the subject of many interesting studies in computer science and computer graphics (Baele and Warzée 2005), but the second point is notably in relation with the grammar used and its formalism. In particular, the time taken to deal with the data structure is obviously linked to the L-string module number and this module number per cycle can quickly increase depending on the implemented rules.

In future studies, we will investigate human performance in tasks involving multimodal interaction with branching structures. Advanced graphic rendering techniques will also be explored in order to increase the realism of the virtual plants, while keeping the real-time aspect.
